facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 636 of 1964 filed.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 636 of 1964. Appeal from the judgment and decree dated September 1, 1959 of the Madras High Court in O. S. Appeal No. 104 of 1955. V. R. Tatachari, for the appellants.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree dated September 1, 1959 of Madras High Court in O.S. Appeal No. 104 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated September 1, 1959 of the Madras High Court in O. S. Appeal No. 104 of 1955. V. R. Tatachari, for the appellants. Thiagarajan, Jayaram and M. R. K. Iyer, for respondents, Nos. 1 and 9.

facts.text: Four mortgages executed between March 20, 1936 and January 2, 1938.

anchor.surface_text: the main question in this appeal relates to the rate of interest payable in respect of four mortgages executed in between March 20, 1936 and January 2, 1938. Both the learned trial Judge, Ramaswami J. of the Madras High Court and the Bench of two Judges in appeal were of the view that the provision for interest in the impugned mortgages should be reduced

facts.text: Mortgages provided for interest at 15 per cent compoundable every quarter.

anchor.surface_text: the learned trial Judge reduced the rate of interest from 15 pet cent companypoundable every quarter to 15 per cent companypoundable with yearly rests, the Judges in appeal after taking all the circumstances into companysideration held that 10 per cent companypound interest with yearly rests would number be excessive

facts.text: Trial Judge Ramaswami J. reduced interest to 15% compoundable with yearly rests.

anchor.surface_text: Both the learned trial Judge, Ramaswami J. of the Madras High Court and the Bench of two Judges in appeal were of the view that the provision for interest in the impugned mortgages should be reduced but whereas the learned trial Judge reduced the rate of interest from 15 pet cent companypoundable every quarter

facts.text: Madras High Court Division Bench reduced interest to 10% compound with yearly rests and 6% from suit institution.

anchor.surface_text: and they reduced the rate accordingly. They also scaled down the rate of interest to 6 per cent from the date of the institution of the suit. The creditor has companye up before this Court in appeal and his substantial companyplaint is that the rate of interest should number have been cut down by the Division Bench of the Madras High Court.

facts.text: Suit filed in the year 1950.

anchor.surface_text: but numberhing came out of it and the suit out of which this appeal has arisen was filed in the year 1950. Other aliences were involved in the suit but we are number companycerned with them.

facts.text: Original mortgagor Dhanakoti Ammal succeeded to properties of her father along with sisters under his will.

anchor.surface_text: The facts of the case may number be briefly stated. The original mortgagor Dhanakoti Ammal had succeeded to the properties of her father along with her sisters under a will executed by him on the basis that the properties were his self-acquired properties.

facts.text: Dhanakoti Ammal's brother Alavandar filed suit in 1919 claiming properties were not self-acquired.

anchor.surface_text: Her brother Alavandar filed a suit in the year 1919 through a next friend claiming that the properties were number the self-acquired properties of his father and as such number capable of bequest under a will. This suit was dismissed as also the appeal therefrom to the Madras High Court preferred in 1922.

facts.text: Alavandar's 1919 suit dismissed; appeal to Madras High Court in 1922 dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: This suit was dismissed as also the appeal therefrom to the Madras High Court preferred in 1922. By the year 1936 when the first mortgage in favour of Srinivasavaradachariar, the appellant, before us, was executed, Dhanakoti Ammal was involved in debts.

facts.text: By 1936, first mortgage to Srinivasavaradachariar (appellant).

anchor.surface_text: By the year 1936 when the first mortgage in favour of Srinivasavaradachariar, the appellant, before us, was executed, Dhanakoti Ammal was involved in debts. The most important item of her properties was a market on the outskirts of the city of Madras which had become dilapidated

facts.text: Dhanakoti Ammal involved in debts by 1936; market property dilapidated, Corporation of Madras refusing license renewal unless repaired.

anchor.surface_text: Dhanakoti Ammal was involved in debts. The most important item of her properties was a market on the outskirts of the city of Madras which had become dilapidated and the Corporation of Madras was refusing to renew the licence unless it was put in good order.

facts.text: Dhanakoti Ammal borrowed sum repayable at 20% compoundable monthly prior to mortgages.

anchor.surface_text: She had further borrowed a sum of money repayable with interest at 20 per cent companypoundable monthly. Her brother Alavandar who was due to attain majority very soon threatened to file another suit impeaching the decree in the earlier suit.

facts.text: Alavandar threatened to file another suit; first two mortgages 1936 before his suit, last mortgage January 1938.

anchor.surface_text: Her brother Alavandar who was due to attain majority very soon threatened to file another suit impeaching the decree in the earlier suit. As a matter of fact, the first two mortgages were executed in 1936 before Alavandar had filed his suit and the last mortgage was executed in January 1938.

facts.text: Dhanakoti Ammal adjudicated insolvent in O.P. 148 of 1949.

anchor.surface_text: Dhanakoti Ammal got more and more involved -in debt and was adjudicated an insolvent in 0. P. 148 of 1949. Her properties got vested in the Official Assignee of Madras.

facts.text: Properties vested in Official Assignee of Madras and sold to Dr. Gopala Menon for Rs. 5,0001-.

anchor.surface_text: Her properties got vested in the Official Assignee of Madras. The Official Assignee brought the properties to sale which were ultimately purchased by Dr. Gopala Menon for Rs. 5,0001-. Dr. Gopala Menon tried to companye to an arrangement with Srinivasavaradachariar

facts.text: Dr. Gopala Menon purchased properties for Rs. 50,001.

anchor.surface_text: purchased by Dr. Gopala Menon for Rs. 5,0001-.

facts.text: Amount advanced under old mortgages nearly Rs. 48,000; prior mortgage nearly Rs. 8,000 due.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges of the Division Bench of the Madras High Court found that the amount advanced under the old mortgages came to nearly Rs. 48,000/- that there was already a prior mortgage in respect of which nearly Rs. 8,000/- was due

facts.text: Trial Judge found risks considerable due to questionable security from brother's suit threat and property condition in Kodambakkam.

anchor.surface_text: According to the learned trial Judge the risks which the creditor ran in advancing the money were companysiderable in that the adequacy of the security was questionable in view of the threat of suit by Dhanakoti Ammals brother and the companydition of the property in an undeveloped area of Kodambakkam.

facts.text: Division Bench held 15% compound quarterly excessive.

anchor.surface_text: and the value of the security though number very ample companyld number be said to be markedly inadequate and there was a shadow on the title of the mortgagor by reason of the threat of suit by her brother. On a companysideration of the entire evidence bearing on the point revealing the circumstances in which the loan transaction came into existence the appellate bench held that 15 per cent companypound interest calculated with quarterly rests was certainly excessive.

facts.text: Appellant advanced further sums after Alavandar's 1937 suit at same rate.

anchor.surface_text: The security was number inadequate and the threat of suit by Alavandar in view of the fact that his earlier suit which had been taken in appeal to the Madras High Court and subsequently lost, was never regarded seriously. This is companyroborated by the fact that even after the institution of that suit in 1937 the appellant before us advanced further sums of money to Dhanakoti Ammal at the same rate of interest as before

facts.text: Supreme Court upholds Division Bench rate of 10% compound yearly rests pre-suit and 6% pendente lite.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion the Division Bench of the Madras High Court made a companyrect assessment of the situation and their pronouncement with regard to the rate of interest prior to the date of the suit ought number to be disturbed. We also find numberreason to interfere with the scaling down of the rate of interest to 6 per cent from the date of the filing of the suit.
s. 3 of the Usurious Loans  Madras Amendment  Act VIII of 1937

concepts.interpretation: Derives court's power to reduce interest, reopen transactions, and relieve debtors from excessive interest if transaction substantially unfair; requires consideration of risk, security, debtor's condition, and other factors to determine excessiveness.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: nd interest with yearly rests would number be excessive and they reduced the rate accordingly. They also scaled down the rate of interest to 6 per cen

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 3, Usurious Loans (Madras Amendment) Act VIII of 1937
concepts.unlisted_description: Empowers courts to grant relief in usurious loan cases by assessing fairness and excessiveness of interest.

anchor.surface_text: Explanation I to the section lays down that if the interest is excessive, the companyrt shall presume that the transaction was substantially unfair but such presumption may be rebutted by a number of special circumstances justifying the rate of interest.

concepts.interpretation: Rebuttable presumption that transaction is substantially unfair if interest is excessive.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: iefs is the reopening of the transaction and relieving the debtor of all liability in respect of any excessive interest. Explanation I to the section

concepts.unlisted_label: Explanation I to Section 3, Usurious Loans (Madras Amendment) Act VIII of 1937

anchor.surface_text: Sub-section  2  of s. 3 provides by clause  a  that the word excessive in the section means in excess of that which the companyrt deems to be reasonable having regard to the risk incurred as it appeared or must be taken to have appeared, to the creditor at the date of the loan.

concepts.interpretation: Defines 'excessive' interest as exceeding what court deems reasonable based on risk apparent to creditor at loan date.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: that which the companyrt deems to be reasonable having regard to the risk incurred as it appeared or must be taken to have appeared, to the creditor

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 3(2)(a), Usurious Loans (Madras Amendment) Act VIII of 1937

anchor.surface_text: Under clause  b  of the said sub- section the companyrt has also to take into account any amounts charged or paid etc. and if companypound interest is charged, the period at which it is calculated and the total advantage which may reasonably be taken to have been expected from the transaction.

concepts.interpretation: Court to consider amounts charged/paid, compound interest periods, and expected advantage from transaction.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: which may reasonably be taken to have been expected from the transaction. Clause  c  of sub-section 2 provides that in companysidering the question o

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 3(2)(b), Usurious Loans (Madras Amendment) Act VIII of 1937

anchor.surface_text: Clause  c  of sub-section 2 provides that in companysidering the question of risk, the companyrt shall take into account the presence or absence of security and the value thereof, the financial companydition of the debtor and the result of any previous transactions of the debtor, by way of loan, so far as the same were known, or must be taken to have been known, to the creditor.

concepts.interpretation: For risk assessment, consider security, its value, debtor's financial condition, and known prior loan results.

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 3(2)(c), Usurious Loans (Madras Amendment) Act VIII of 1937

anchor.surface_text: Clause  d  of the said sub-section enjoins upon the companyrt to companysider also all circumstances materially affecting the relations the parties at the time of the loan or tending to show that the transaction was unfair, including the necessities or supposed necessities of the debtor at the time of the loan so far as the same were known, or must be taken to have been known, to the creditor.

concepts.interpretation: Consider all material circumstances affecting parties' relations, showing unfairness, including debtor's known necessities.

issues.text: Whether the rate of interest should be scaled down to 6 per cent from the date of the institution of the suit

anchor.surface_text: They also scaled down the rate of interest to 6 per cent from the date of the institution of the suit. The creditor has come up before this Court in appeal and his substantial complaint is that the rate of interest should not have been cut down by the Division Bench of the Madras High Court.

issues.text: Whether 15 per cent compound interest with quarterly rests was excessive having regard to the circumstances including risk, security, debtor's condition under s.3 of the Usurious Loans Madras Amendment Act VIII of 1937

anchor.surface_text: s. 3 of the Usurious Loans  Madras Amendment  Act VIII of 1937. Sub-section  1  of that section gives the court the power to give relief in various ways if it has reason to believe that the transaction as between the parties thereto was substantially unfair. One of such reliefs is the reopening of the transaction and relieving the debtor of all liability in respect of any excessive interest. Explanation I to the section lays down that if the interest is excessive, the court shall presume that the transaction was substantially unfair but such presumption may be rebutted by a number of special circumstances justifying the rate of interest.

issues.text: Whether there is reason to interfere with the Division Bench's discretion in scaling down interest pendente lite to 6 per cent

arguments.claim: No reason to interfere with Division Bench's scaling down to 6% pendente lite given long delay since 1936/38 mortgages and interest already exceeding principal

anchor.surface_text: We also find no reason to interfere with the scaling down of the rate of interest to 6 per cent from the date of the filing of the suit. Although the reasons are not indicated, it seems fairly plain that their Lordships were using their discretion as regards interest pendente lite. We cannot overlook the fact that the mortgages were executed as far back as 1936 and 1938 and that the creditor who had waited till 1950 for the institution of the suit would, in any event, get interest substantially exceeding the principal amount of the loans.

arguments.claim: 10% compound yearly better for creditor than 12% simple over years

anchor.surface_text: There can be no dispute that interest payable at the rate of 10 per cent compoundable annually over a number of years would be more in the interest of the creditor than 12 per cent per annum simple for the same period.
